result.execSummary:
The defendant Elijuwon M. Clawson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Retail Theft - Intentionally Take (<=$500), a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.50(1m)(b).
  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

Statement Regarding Recusal - Molepski, Jr/Judge Finn

Defendant Elijuwon M. Clawson in court with attorney Anne Renc. David R. Knaapen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

9:58 AM Court calls case.
Atty Knaapen states appearances.

There is a plea agreement.

Court file should obtain an amended information.

Defendant will plead to Count 1 and Count 2.
Count 3 would be dismissed and read in.

Atty Knaapen states the plea agreement.
Atty Renc addresses the Court regarding the agreement.

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Atty Renc has received a copy of the information and waives reading.

Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST Count 1
Defendant enters a plea of: NO CONTEST Count 2

Court questions Defendant regarding pleas.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.

Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Both attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charges.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charges.
Court finds the defendant guilty.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
Count 1: 943.50(1m)(b)(4a)
Count 2: 946.49(1)(a)
Count 3: Dismissed and Read In

Atty Knaapen makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 
Atty Renc makes sentencing arguments to the Court. 

Court agrees with the recommendations under the circumstances.

BY THE COURT:
Count 1:
180 Days Jail Sentence, Imposed and Stayed
32 Days Jail credit in the event that Defendant is revoked
Huber granted for work and any mental treatment
Placed on Probation for a period of 24 Months concurrent with supervision Defendant is under now, from Wood County, being served in Dane County
Conditions:
Have a mental heath assessment. If one is done, then comply with all mental health treatment
Participate in any counseling as recommended by the agent
Write a letter of apology to Shopko Store
Not to be on the premises of  Shopko Store in Stevens Point
Pay Restitution in the amount of $173.81
Pay costs
Pay DNA Surcharge

Count 2:
180 Days Jail Sentence, Imposed and Stayed, concurrent to Count 1
Huber granted for work and any mental treatment
Placed on Probation for a period of 24 Months, concurrent to Count 1 and concurrent with the Wood County supervision
Conditions:
Comply with conditions of probation as stated in Count 1
Pay costs
Pay DNA Surcharge

Defendant Elijuwon M. Clawson appeared by video. Prosecuting Atty David R. Knaapen with Intern Taylor Kraus appeared for State of Wisconsin.
Court questions defendant re: counsel.

Court advises defendant of right to counsel/Public Defender representation.
Defendant indicates he is represented by Atty Jerabek in Wood County.  Who is appointed by the Court.

Atty Drury indicates he was evaluated and is eligible but indicated he did not want a lawyer appointed. 

Court continues for 1 week to allow for the appointment of counsel.
